title: It 'feels like a recession' to a lot of people: ANZ
text:
He said other companies could also be slow responding to lower funding costs in the wake of official rate cuts and “that is having a real impact on business investment”. The issue has previously been identified by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

While Mr Elliott considered it unlikely that Australia would enter an official recession, he told the Arnold Bloch Leibler event that “many households feel they have less discretionary income” and economic growth is “below its potential”.

Furthermore, the Reserve Bank’s official rate cut earlier this month had a limited short-term impact because “unfortunately, the relief from low interest rates is starting to be poured back into housing. [Consumers] are not spending it on retail or other things”.

Lending grey line

After ANZ mortgage volumes were crippled by an over-conservative approach to responsible lending, Mr Elliott said this was starting to correct itself.

After meeting with the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and Australian Securities and Investments Commission this week, he said ANZ was cautiously moving back towards the “grey line” of what is a responsible loan, after “staying away from the line because it is too hard” during the uncertainty of the banking royal commission.

“We are still not really sure where the line is … but we are slowly crawling back to where we see the line. It will work itself out when it is clarified by the courts and ASIC – that will slowly build up confidence," he said. "But it’s been dislocating for customers."

Open banking risks

Advertisement

The government’s open banking regime could provide banks with their next headache, Mr Elliott suggested, given it will allow big data to be used to price loans based on individual borrowers’ risks. This could lead to more discriminatory pricing, which raised questions about equity and access to finance.

“You are going to see the emergence of targeted, nuanced banking – and the big question for the community is that in the old system, everyone paid about the same. But in a world of risk-based pricing, who will get the best deals? People with money. So there will be social implications of that.”

The banking industry is facing “massive change” from empowered regulators, more scrutiny, and new technology facilitating switching, Mr Elliott said. Even though banks remain profitable and serve customers well, “internally, it feels like we are in a crisis,” he told the lunch.

Repeating a theme in a speech to the Intersekt fintech festival last week, Mr Elliott said it was hard to know which technology giants would be competitors in the future. “We need to change our business to respond to that otherwise we will be in serious trouble,” he said.

ANZ will release its full-year results on October 31.
description: ANZ boss Shayne Elliott said many customers felt like the economy was in recession as savings from the latest round of rate cuts were used to reduce housing debt.
